revision.text:
'''The International Neuromodulation Society''' ('''INS''') is a [[non-profit]] group of clinicians, scientists and engineers dedicated to the scientific development and awareness of [[Neuromodulation (medicine)|neuromodulation]]<ref>[http://www.neuromodulation.com/a-brief-history-of-neuromodulation.htm A Brief History of Neuromodulation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> – the alteration of nerve activity through the delivery of electromagnetic stimulation or chemical agents to targeted sites of the body. Neuromodulation is a burgeoning field – analysts predicted a 27 percent annual growth rate through 2012.<ref>[http://www.neurotechreports.com/pages/marketprojections12.html Worldwide market for neurotechnology products, neural prostheses, neuromodulation, neurorehabilitation, neurosensing, cochlear implants, deep brain stimulation (DBS) systems, neurorobotics<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Founded in 1989 and based in San Francisco, CA, the INS educates and promotes the field through meetings, its bimonthly, peer-reviewed journal ''[[Neuromodulation: Technology at the Neural Interface]]'' and chapter websites.
[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1525-1403 ''Neuromodulation: Technology at the Neural Interface''] is the official publication of the INS. The peer-reviewed journal aims to advance the basic and clinical science of the field of neuromodulation. Published 8 times per year, the journal is MEDLINE-indexed.
==History== In 1989, after the first International Congress on Epidural Spinal Cord Stimulation was held in the [[Netherlands]], a group of physicians founded the INS in [[Paris]], [[France]]. Their incentive was to bridge the gap between [[neurologist]]s, [[neurosurgeon]]s, [[vascular surgeon]]s and [[cardiologist]]s to build a multidisciplinary and international society dedicated to the advancement of neuromodulation.
==Today== The International Neuromodulation Society now represents a professional association of more than 1700 members worldwide and has a presence in 33 countries around the globe. The INS was named the [http://www.neurotechreports.com/pages/goldelectrodes07.html 2007 Most Valuable Nonprofit Society] by Neurotech Reports and was awarded the Golden Electrode Award at the [http://www.neurotechreports.com/pages/leadersforum.html 2007 Neurotech Leaders Forum. ]
INS members actively work to inform peers and patients about this new class of therapies through organizational collaboration, articles, professional presentations, and [http://www.neuromodulation.com/for-patients web content].
==Regional chapters== ===Chapter societies worldwide=== * [http://sane.org.ar/ Argentinean Neuromodulation Society (SANE)] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/australia Neuromodulation Society of Australia and New Zealand] * [https://bns.memberclicks.net/ Benelux Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/brazil Brazilian Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/canada Canadian Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/china Chinese Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/france French Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.dgnm-online.de/ German Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/india/ The Neuromodulation Society of India] * [http://www.insneuromodulazione.it/ Italian Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/japan Japan Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/korea Korean Neuromodulation Society] * [http://nordicneuro.org/ Nordic Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/north-america---home North American Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/poland Polish Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/south-africa South Africa Neuromodulation Society] * [http://neuromodulationsociety.gr/ Southeast European Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/spain Spanish Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.ch/ Swiss Neuromodulation Society] * [http://www.neuromodulation.com/turkey Turkish Neuromodulation Society] * [https://nsuki.memberclicks.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=55 The Neuromodulation Society of the United Kingdom and Ireland]
==Biennial congress== The 14th World [http://www.neuromodulation.com/ins-congress Congress] of the INS will be held in [[Sydney, Australia]] in 2019.
==Official journal== The official journal of the International Neuromodulation Society is ''[[Neuromodulation: Technology at the Neural Interface]]''. This journal is the preeminent journal in the area of neuromodulation, providing its readership with state of the art clinical, translational and basic science research in the field as well as representing the needs of the neuromodulation community.
==Timeline== * 1992: The first scientific meeting of the INS was held in Rome, Italy. * 1995: The [[North American Neuromodulation Society]] (NANS), the first chapter of the INS, was founded. * 1998: The INS' journal, ''Neuromodulation'', was first published. * 1999: The Italian Neuromodulation Society was founded. * 2001: The Neuromodulation Society of the United Kingdom & Ireland (NSUKI) was founded. * 2002: The Benelux Neuromodulation Society was founded. * 2004: The Australian Neuromodulation Society was formed. * 2005: The German, Japan and Southeast European Neuromodulation Societies were founded. * 2006: The North American Neuromodulation Society hosted its 10th annual meeting. * 2007: The Spanish Neuromodulation Society was formed. In addition, five new national chapters joined the INS: Brazil, Canada, China, France and Korea. * 2008: The INS announced it represents a professional association of more than 1200 members worldwide. * 2009: The Argentinean Neuromodulation Society (SANE) was founded.
==See also== * [[Neurotechnology]] ==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.neuromodulation.com The International Neuromodulation Society] * [http://northamerica.neuromodulation.com/north-american-neuromodulation-society-home.htm North American Neuromodulation Society ] * [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118536370/home ''Neuromodulation: Technology at the Neural Interface'' Journal] * [http://www.ifess.org The International Functional Electrical Stimulation Society (IFESS)] * [http://www.ninds.nih.gov National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)] * [http://www.neurotechreports.com Neurotech Reports] * [http://www.neurotechnetwork.org Neurotech Network] * [http://www.neurotechindustry.org Neurotech Industry Organization] [[Category:Neuroscience organizations]] [[Category:Neurotechnology]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in California]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1989]] [[Category:Medical associations based in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{short description|14th and 15th-century French princess and queen of England}} {{Other people|Isabella of Valois}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox royalty | consort = yes | image =Isabelle Valois.jpg | title =Duchess of Orléans | succession =[[List of English consorts|Queen consort of England]] | reign =1 November 1396 – 30 September 1399 | coronation =8 January 1397 | spouse =[[Richard II of England]]
[[Charles, Duke of Orléans]] | house =[[House of Valois|Valois]] | issue =[[Joan of Valois, Duchess of Alençon]] | father =[[Charles VI of France]] | mother =[[Isabella of Bavaria]] | birth_date =9 November 1389 | birth_place =Paris, France | death_date =13 September 1409 (aged 19) | death_place =[[Blois]], Loir-et-Cher, France }} '''Isabella of France''' (9 November 1389 – 13 September 1409) was [[Queen consort of England]] as the second spouse of King [[Richard II of England|Richard II]]. Her parents were [[Charles VI of France|King Charles VI of France]] and [[Isabeau of Bavaria]]. She married the king at the age of seven and was widowed three years later. She later married [[Charles, Duke of Orléans]], dying in childbirth at the age of nineteen. Isabella's younger sister, [[Catherine of Valois|Catherine]], was Queen of England from 1420 until 1422, married to [[Henry V of England|Henry V]] and mother of [[Henry VI of England|Henry VI]]. ==Life== [[File:Isabela richard2.jpg|thumb|left|Richard and Isabella on their wedding day]] Isabella lived during a period of political tension between France and England known as the [[Hundred Years War]], the situation made worse by the mental instability of her father. On 31 October 1396, almost the age of seven, Isabella married the widower King [[Richard II of England]] in a move for peace with France.{{sfn|Hamilton|2010|p=205}} The fact that she was a child was discussed during the negotiations, but Richard replied that each day would rectify that problem, that it was an advantage as he would then be able to shape her in accordance with his ideal, and that he was young enough to wait. Isabella herself told the English envoys that she was happy to be Queen of England, because she had been told that this would make her a great lady. She is described as pretty, and reportedly practiced in order to be able to perform her role as queen. King Richard traveled to Paris to fetch her, where the wedding was celebrated with grand festivities at the French royal court, before they continued to the English enclave of Calais, where the formal wedding ceremony was performed on 31 October. ===Queen of England=== After the wedding, Queen Isabella followed Richard to England, where she was placed in Windsor Castle with her own court under the supervision of her appointed governess and chief lady-in-waiting Lady de Coucy (later replaced by Lady Mortimer). She was formally crowned Queen of England in Westminster in London the following year, 1397. Although the union was political and an arranged marriage, Richard II and the child Isabella developed a mutually respectful relationship: Richard regularly visited her in Windsor, where he treated her with respect and entertained her and her ladies-in-waiting with humorous conversation, and Isabella reportedly enjoyed and looked forward to his visits. By May 1399, the Queen had been moved to [[Portchester Castle]] for protection while Richard went on a military campaign in Ireland. During the following rebellion against Richard, Isabella was moved by the Duke of York first to Wallingford Castle and then to Leeds Castle. When on his return to England Richard II was imprisoned and died in custody, Queen Isabella was ordered by the new King [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]] to move out of [[Windsor Castle]] and to settle in the [[Bishop of Salisbury]]'s Thamesside [[Sonning Bishop's Palace|palace]] at [[Sonning]] in formal house arrest. ===Later life=== In 1400, the deposed king was killed, and the French court requested that Isabella return to France. King Henry IV initially refused, deciding Queen Isabella should marry his son, the future [[Henry V of England]], but she refused. Knowing her spouse was dead, she went into mourning, ignoring Henry IV's demands. In August 1401, he let her go back to France, but kept her [[dowry]].{{sfn|Stratford|2012|p=14, 118}} In 1406, Henry IV repeated his suggestion that Isabella marry his son, but it was refused by the French court. On 29 June 1406, Queen Isabella, aged 16, married her cousin, [[Charles, Duke of Orléans]], aged 11.{{sfn|Knecht|2007|p=51}} She died in childbirth at the age of 19. Her surviving daughter, [[Jeanne of Valois (1409-1432)|Joan]], married [[John II of Alençon]] in 1424. Isabella's body was interred in Blois, in the abbey of [[St. Laumer]], where it was later discovered in 1624, curiously wrapped in bands of linen plated over with [[Mercury (element)|quicksilver]]. It was then transferred to the church of the [[Celestines]] in Paris. ==In literature== In Shakespeare's play ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' Richard's queen appears in two significant scenes at the time of his deposition, but she is portrayed as an adult. She is forced by the new king Henry IV to leave for France after the deposition. Two children's novels about Isabella's life appeared in the late 1950s, [[Hilda Lewis]]' ''[[The Gentle Falcon]]'' and [[Gladys Malvern]]'s ''My Lady, My Love.'' Isabella appears in the historical novel ''[[In a Dark Wood Wandering]]'' (original Dutch title ''Het woud der verwachting'') by [[Hella Haasse]], which centers on the life of her second husband Charles, Duke of Orléans. ==Arms== {{Infobox COA wide |image = Arms of Isabella of Valois.svg |bannerimage = |badgeimage = |notes = Isabella's arms were those of her father, Charles VI of France, impaled with the royal coat of arms of the England. Rendered as per pale of three.{{sfn|Boutell|1863|p=148}} |adopted = 1397 |crest = |torse = |helm = |escutcheon = France Ancient; impaled by Richard II. |supporters = |compartment = |motto = |orders = |other_elements = |banner = |badge = |symbolism = |previous_versions = }} ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Isabella de Valois of France''' |2= 2. [[Charles VI of France]] |3= 3. [[Isabeau of Bavaria]] |4= 4. [[Charles V of France]] |5= 5. [[Joanna of Bourbon|Jeanne of Bourbon]] |6= 6. [[Stephen III, Duke of Bavaria]] |7= 7. [[Taddea Visconti]] |8= 8. [[John II of France]] |9= 9. [[Bonne of Bohemia|Bonne of Luxembourg and Bohemia]] |10= 10. [[Peter I, Duke of Bourbon]] |11= 11. [[Isabella of Valois (1313-1388)|Isabelle of Valois]] |12= 12. [[Stephen II, Duke of Bavaria]] |13= 13. [[Elisabeth of Sicily, Duchess of Bavaria|Elisabeth of Sicily]] |14= 14. [[Bernabò Visconti]] |15= 15. [[Beatrice Regina della Scala]] |16= 16. [[Philip VI of France]] |17= 17. [[Joan the Lame|Joan of Burgundy]] |18= 18. [[John of Bohemia|John of Luxembourg, King of Bohemia]] |19= 19. [[Elisabeth of Bohemia (1292-1330)|Elisabeth of Bohemia]] |20= 20. [[Louis I, Duke of Bourbon]] |21= 21. [[Mary of Avesnes]] |22= 22. [[Charles of Valois]] |23= 23. [[Mahaut of Châtillon]] |24= 24. [[Louis IV, Holy Roman Emperor]] |25= 25. [[Beatrix of Silesia-Glogau]] |26= 26. [[Frederick III of Sicily]] |27= 27. [[Eleanor of Anjou]] |28= 28. [[Stefano Visconti]] |29= 29. Valentina Doria |30= 30. [[Mastino II della Scala]] |31= 31. Taddea da Carrara }} ==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{citation|last=Boutell|first=Charles|authorlink=Charles Boutell|title=A Manual of Heraldry, Historical and Popular|year=1863|publisher=Winsor & Newton|location=London|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |first=Jeffrey |last=Hamilton |title=The Plantagenets: History of a Dynasty |publisher=Continuum |year=2010 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Knecht |title=The Valois: Kings of France 1328–1589 |publisher=Hambledon Continuum |year=2007 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |title=Richard II and the English Royal Treasure |first=Jenny |last=Stratford |publisher=The Boydell Press |year=2012 |ref=harv}} {{S-start}} {{S-roy|en}} |- {{S-vac| last=[[Anne of Bohemia]] }} {{S-ttl| title =[[List of English consorts|Queen consort of England]]
[[List of Irish consorts|Lady of Ireland]] | years = 31 October 1396 – 30 September 1399}} {{S-vac| next= [[Joan of Navarre, Queen of England|Joanna of Navarre]]}} {{s-end}} {{English consort}} {{Duchesses of Orléans}} {{House of Plantagenet}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Isabella Of Valois}} [[Category:Irish royal consorts]] [[Category:1389 births]] [[Category:1409 deaths]] [[Category:French princesses]] [[Category:English royal consorts]] [[Category:People of the Hundred Years' War]] [[Category:House of Valois]] [[Category:Ladies of the Garter]] [[Category:15th-century English women]] [[Category:People from Sonning]] [[Category:Deaths in childbirth]] [[Category:Duchesses of Orléans]] [[Category:14th-century French people]] [[Category:15th-century French people]] [[Category:14th-century English people]] [[Category:15th-century English people]] [[Category:14th-century French women]] [[Category:15th-century French women]] [[Category:14th-century English women]] [[Category:Richard II of England]]

{{For|architect's son, also a prominent architect|James Gallier Jr. }} {{Infobox architect |name = James Gallier |image = |image_size = |caption = |nationality = |birth_name=James Gallagher |birth_date = July 24, 1798 |birth_place = Ravensdale, Ireland |death_date = {{death-date and age|October 3, 1866|July 24, 1798}} |death_place = At sea, east of [[Tybee Island, Georgia]] |practice = |significant_buildings= [[Gallier Hall]], [[Preservation Resource Center|the Leeds-Davis Building]], [[Christ Church Cathedral (New Orleans)|the Second Christ Church Cathedral]] |significant_projects = |significant_design = |awards = }} '''James Gallier''' (July 24, 1798 – October 3, 1866) was a prominent 19th-century New Orleans architect.
==Biography==
===Early life=== He was born '''James Gallagher''' in Ravensdale, [[County Louth]], [[Ireland]] in 1798.<ref name="banks">{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-19484799.html |title=The Galliers, New Orleans architects. |date=1997-04-01 | author=Banks, William Nathaniel |accessdate=2008-01-30|work=|publisher=The Magazine Antiques, republished in HighBeam Encyclopedia}}</ref> He changed his last name to a French surname when he moved to New Orleans (1834).<ref>http://www.nola.com/175years/index.ssf/2012/01/the_galliers_the_times-picayun.html "The Galliers," ''Times-Picayune, 29 January 2012''.</ref>
===Career=== He worked in England during his early career, designing the [[Godmanchester Chinese Bridge]] which crosses a mill stream of the [[River Great Ouse]] in 1827, and then working on the redevelopment of the Grosvenor Estate in Mayfair. He became bankrupt, and emigrated to America<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=41847 ''The Architecture of the Estate: The Reign of the Cundys'', Survey of London: volume 39: The Grosvenor Estate in Mayfair, Part 1 (General History) (1977), pp. 127-140.]</ref> in 1832.
He was one of a group of architects who created the idea of Architectural Practice, with the architect working for the clients, and managing those who actually build the structures that have been designed.<ref>''From Craft to Profession: The Practice of Architecture in Nineteenth-Century America'', (1999), Mary N. Woods, University of California Press, {{ISBN|978-0-520-21494-1}}</ref>
His significant works that are [[National Historic Landmarks]] include: * [[Gallier Hall]] on St. Charles Avenue (1851), at Lafayette Square in the [[New Orleans Central Business District|Central Business District]], which was New Orleans' City Hall for nearly a century. It is a National Historic Landmark. * [[Pontalba Buildings]], with [[Henry Howard (architect)|Henry Howard]], a National Historic Landmark. * [[St. Charles Hotel, New Orleans|St. Charles Hotel]] * [[Government Street Presbyterian Church]] (1836), a National Historic Landmark in [[Mobile, Alabama]].
His other significant works include: * [[Christ Church Cathedral, New Orleans|The Second Christ Church Cathedral]] on [[St. Charles Avenue]] (1837), an [[Episcopal Diocese of Louisiana|Episcopalian Church]] and later a [[synagogue]]. No longer exists. * [[Barton Academy]] (1836) in Mobile, Alabama. * [[Belle Helene]] (1850) in [[Ascension Parish, Louisiana]]. * [[The Boston Club]] (1844) for Dr William Newton Mercer
===Personal life and death=== In 1823, while in England, he met and married Elizabeth Tyler. Their only surviving child was [[James Gallier Jr.]], who also became an architect. Elizabeth died in July 1844, in her mid-forties.
On June 23, 1850, in [[Charleston, South Carolina]], he married Catherine Maria Robinson of [[Mobile, Alabama]], who was born November 18, 1822, in [[Hardwick, Massachusetts]], to Colonel Joseph Robinson and Ann Maria Ruggles Walton. She was 24 years his junior.
On October 3, 1866, Mr. and Mrs. Gallier were passengers on board the ''Evening Star'', a paddle-wheel [[Steamboat|steamer]] en route from [[New York City]] to New Orleans, when it sank in a [[hurricane]] about 175 miles east of [[Savannah, Georgia]]. There were only a half-dozen survivors out of approximately 250 people.<ref>[http://www.neworleansbar.org/documents/ENews08Nostalgia0528N.O.in1867.pdf ''New Orleans in 1867'', (2008), Ned Hemard, New Orleans Bar Association], accessed 2009-10-31</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} Pierson Jr., William H. The Colonial and Neo-Classical Styles, vol.1, American Buildings and Their Architects (New York: Anchor Books,1976),456.
==External links== * [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0306712474 Autobiography of James Gallier.] {{ISBN|0-306-71247-4}}. * [http://seaa.tulane.edu/ Southeastern Architectural Archive, Tulane University] * [http://www.knowla.org/entry/815/&view=summary James Gallier in ''KnowLA, Encyclopedia of Louisiana'']
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gallier, James}} [[Category:19th-century American architects]] [[Category:1798 births]] [[Category:1866 deaths]] [[Category:Greek Revival architects]] [[Category:Irish emigrants to the United States (before 1923)]] [[Category:People from County Louth]] [[Category:People who died at sea]] [[Category:People lost at sea]] [[Category:Deaths due to shipwreck]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox baseball biography |name=John Roseboro |image=Johnny Roseboro 1957.png |caption=Roseboro in 1957 |position=[[Catcher]] |birth_date={{Birth date|1933|5|13}} |birth_place=[[Ashland, Ohio]] |death_date={{death date and age|2002|8|16|1933|5|13}} |death_place=[[Los Angeles, California]] |bats=Left |throws=Right |debutleague = MLB |debutdate=June 14 |debutyear=1957 |debutteam=Brooklyn Dodgers |finalleague = MLB |finaldate=August 11 |finalyear=1970 |finalteam=Washington Senators |statleague = MLB |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.249 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=104 |stat3label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat3value=548 |teams= * [[Los Angeles Dodgers|Brooklyn / Los Angeles Dodgers]] ({{mlby|1957}}–{{mlby|1967}}) * [[Minnesota Twins]] ({{mlby|1968}}–{{mlby|1969}}) * [[Washington Senators (1961–71)|Washington Senators]] ({{mlby|1970}}) |highlights= * 6× [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] ([[1958 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1958]], [[1961 Major League Baseball All-Star Game (first game)|1961]]–[[1962 Major League Baseball All-Star Game (second game)|1962²]], [[1969 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1969]]) * 3× [[World Series]] champion ({{wsy|1959}}, {{wsy|1963}}, {{wsy|1965}}) * 2× [[Gold Glove Award]] (1961, 1966) }} '''John Junior Roseboro''' (May 13, 1933 – August 16, 2002) was an [[Americans|American]] professional [[baseball]] player and [[Coach (baseball)|coach]].<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference">{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/rosebjo01.shtml |title=John Roseboro at Baseball Reference |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> He played as a [[catcher]] in [[Major League Baseball]] from 1957 until 1970, most notably for the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]]. Roseboro was a four-time [[MLB All-Star Game|All-Star]] player and won two [[Rawlings Gold Glove Award|Gold Glove Awards]] for his defensive skills. He was the Dodgers' starting catcher in four [[World Series]] with the Dodgers winning three of those.<ref name=NYT1>{{cite news|last1=Goldstein|first1=Richard|title=John Roseboro, a Dodgers Star, Dies at 69|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/20/sports/john-roseboro-a-dodgers-star-dies-at-69.html|accessdate=26 December 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=August 20, 2002}}</ref> He is considered one of the best defensive catchers of the 1960s.<ref name="The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract">{{cite book |author=James, Bill |title=[[The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract]] |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |year=2001 |page= 392 |isbn=0-684-80697-5}}</ref> Roseboro was known for his role in one of the most violent incidents in baseball history when [[Juan Marichal]] struck him in the head with a [[Baseball bat|bat]] during a game in {{Baseball year|1965}}.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name="John Roseboro Dies">{{cite news |title=John Roseboro Dies |agency=Los Angeles Times |work=The Spokesman Review |page=C5 |date=20 August 2002 |accessdate=30 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=20020820&id=6mVWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jPIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5049,8857010&hl=en}}</ref>
==Baseball career== ===Early life in professional baseball=== Roseboro was born in [[Ashland, Ohio]] and enrolled at [[Central State University]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Meet A Dodger |agency= |work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |page=17 |date=1 March 1959 |accessdate=30 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1755&dat=19390301&id=7pkcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D2UEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5997,102077&hl=en}}</ref> He was signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers as an amateur free agent prior to the [[1952 Brooklyn Dodgers season|1952]] season and, began his [[professional baseball]] career with the [[Sheboygan Indians]] of the [[Wisconsin State League]].<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/><ref name="John Roseboro minor league statistics">{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/player.cgi?id=rosebo001joh |title=John Roseboro minor league statistics |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> He posted a .365 [[batting average]] with Sheboygan in 1952 to finish second in the league batting championship.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/leader.cgi?type=bat&id=8c53a924 |title=1952 Wisconsin State League Batting Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> Roseboro missed the 1954 season due to military service but, after five years in the [[Minor league baseball|minor leagues]], he was promoted to the major leagues in June 1957 at the age of 24.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Johnny_Roseboro |title=Johnny Roseboro |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref>
===Campanella's heir apparent=== During his first season, Roseboro served as backup catcher for the Dodgers' perennial All-Star catcher, [[Roy Campanella]], and was being groomed to be Campanella's replacement. However, he was promoted to the starting catcher's position ahead of schedule when Campanella had a tragic car accident in January 1958 that ended his career.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scouts Rave Over New Campy In Praising John Roseboro |agency=ANP |work=Washington Afro-American |page=13 |date=5 February 1957 |accessdate=30 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2238&dat=19570205&id=EuElAAAAIBAJ&sjid=o_QFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5430,1091082&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=John Roseboro Is Learning Fast As Replacement For Roy Campanella |agency= |work=The Day |page=16 |date=17 March 1959 |accessdate=30 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19590317&id=9qs0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=EHMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=911,1829623&hl=en}}</ref> In his first full season, with the team having moved to Los Angeles, Roseboro hit for a .271 batting average along with 14 [[home run]]s and 43 [[runs batted in]].<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/> He was also named as a reserve player for the [[National League]] in the [[1958 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1958 All-Star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ALS/ALS195807080.shtml |title=1958 All-Star game |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> In [[1959 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1959]], Roseboro led the league's catchers in [[putout]]s and in baserunners [[caught stealing]], helping the Dodgers win the [[List of National League pennant winners|National League Pennant]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1959-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1959 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1959.shtml |title=1959 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> The Dodgers went on to win the [[1959 World Series]], defeating the [[1959 Chicago White Sox season|Chicago White Sox]] in six games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1959_WS.shtml |title=1959 World Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref>
After having a below par season in [[1960 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1960]], Roseboro rebounded in [[1961 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1961]] posting career highs with 18 home runs and 59 runs batted in.<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/> He also led the National League catchers in putouts and [[double play]]s and finished second in [[fielding percentage]] and in [[Assist (baseball)|assists]] to earn his first Gold Glove Award as, the Dodgers finished the season in second place behind the [[1961 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1961-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1961 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1961 |title=1961 National League Gold Glove Award winners |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1961.shtml |title=1961 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> He also earned his second All-Star team berth as a reserve player in the [[1961 Major League Baseball All-Star Game (second game)|1961 All-Star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NLS/NLS196107110.shtml |title=1961 All-Star game |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> He won his third All-Star berth as a reserve in the [[1962 Major League Baseball All-Star Game (first game)|1962 All-Star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ALS/ALS196207100.shtml |title=1962 All-Star game |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> The Dodgers battled the [[1962 San Francisco Giants season|San Francisco Giants]] in a tight pennant race during the [[1962 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1962]] season with the two teams ending the season tied for first place and met in the [[1962 National League tie-breaker series]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1962.shtml |title=1962 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> The Giants won the three-game series to clinch the National League championship.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=mlb&id=3617483|title=Tiebreaker Playoff Results|work=[[ESPN.com]]|date=September 30, 2008|accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref>
Roseboro helped guide the Dodgers' pitching staff to a league leading 2.85 [[earned run average]] in [[1963 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1963]] as the Dodgers clinched the National League Pennant by 6 games over the [[1963 St. Louis Cardinals season|St. Louis Cardinals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1963.shtml |title=1963 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1963.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::7 |title=1963 National League Team Pitching Statistics |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> Roseboro made his presence felt in the [[1963 World Series]] against the [[1963 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] when he hit a three-run home run off [[Whitey Ford]] to win the first game of the series.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYA/NYA196310020.shtml |title=1963 World Series Game 1 box score |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> The Dodgers went on to win the series by defeating the Yankees in four straight games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1963_WS.shtml |title=1963 World Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> The Dodgers dropped to seventh place in the [[1964 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1964]] season, however Roseboro hit for a career high .287 batting average and led the league's catchers with a 60.4% caught stealing percentage.<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1964-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1964 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref>
===Marichal incident=== Roseboro was involved in a major altercation with [[Juan Marichal]] during a game between the Dodgers and [[San Francisco Giants]] at [[Candlestick Park]] on August 22, {{Baseball year|1965}}.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name="The Battle Of San Francisco">{{cite web |last=Mann |first=Jack |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1965/08/30/605969/the-battle-of-san-francisco |title=The Battle Of San Francisco |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=August 30, 1965 |accessdate=December 30, 2015}}</ref> The Giants and the Dodgers had nurtured a heated [[Dodgers–Giants rivalry|rivalry]] with each other dating back to their days together in the New York City market.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball">{{cite news |title=Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball |agency=Associated Press |work=The Times-News |page=18 |date=22 August 1990 |accessdate=31 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1665&dat=19900822&id=llYaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tSQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6791,5769085&hl=en}}</ref> As the 1965 season neared its climax, the Dodgers were involved in a tight pennant race, entering the game leading the [[1965 Milwaukee Braves season|Milwaukee Braves]] by half a game and the Giants by one and a half games.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> The incident occurred in the aftermath of the [[Watts riots]] near Roseboro's Los Angeles home and while the [[Dominican Civil War]] raged in Marichal's home country, so emotions were raw.<ref name="Marichal, Roseboro and the inside story of baseball's nastiest brawl">{{cite web |last=Rosengren |first=John |url=https://www.si.com/mlb/2014/04/21/juan-marichal-johnny-roseboro-brawl-excerpt |title=Marichal, Roseboro and the inside story of baseball's nastiest brawl |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=2014 |accessdate=December 31, 2015}}</ref>
[[Maury Wills]] led off the game with a [[Bunt (baseball)|bunt]] single off Marichal, and eventually scored a [[Run (baseball)|run]] when [[Ron Fairly]] hit a [[Double (baseball)|double]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/SFN/SFN196508220.shtml |title=August 22, 1965 Dodgers-Giants box score |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=31 December 2015 }}</ref> Marichal, a fierce competitor, viewed the bunt as a cheap way to get on base and took umbrage with Wills.<ref name="The Battle Of San Francisco"/><ref name="Marichal, Roseboro and the inside story of baseball's nastiest brawl"/> When Wills came up to bat in the second [[Inning (baseball)|inning]], Marichal threw a pitch directly at Wills sending him sprawling to the ground.<ref name="The Battle Of San Francisco"/> [[Willie Mays]] then led off the bottom of the second inning for the Giants and Dodgers' pitcher [[Sandy Koufax]] threw a pitch over Mays' head as a token form of retaliation.<ref name="The Battle Of San Francisco"/><ref name="Marichal, Roseboro and the inside story of baseball's nastiest brawl"/> In the top of the third inning with two [[Out (baseball)|outs]], Marichal threw a [[fastball]] that came close to hitting Fairly, prompting him to dive to the ground.<ref name="Marichal, Roseboro and the inside story of baseball's nastiest brawl"/> Marichal's act angered the Dodgers sitting in the [[Dugout (baseball)|dugout]] and home plate umpire [[Shag Crawford]] then warned both teams that any further retaliations would not be tolerated.<ref name="Marichal, Roseboro and the inside story of baseball's nastiest brawl"/>
Marichal came to bat in the third inning expecting Koufax to take further retaliation against him but instead, he was startled when Roseboro's return throw to Koufax after the second pitch either brushed his ear or came close enough for him to feel the breeze off the ball.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> When Marichal confronted Roseboro about the proximity of his throw, Roseboro came out of his crouch with his fists clenched.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> Marichal afterwards stated that he thought Roseboro was about to attack him and raised his bat, striking Roseboro at least twice over the head with his bat, opening a two-inch gash that sent blood flowing down the catcher's face that required 14 stitches.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/><ref name="Put up your dukes">{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/basebrawl.html |title=Put up your dukes |publisher=espn.go.com |accessdate=4 January 2016 }}</ref> Koufax raced in from the mound to attempt to separate them and was joined by the umpires, players and coaches from both teams.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/>
A 14-minute brawl ensued on the field before Koufax, Giants captain Willie Mays and other peacemakers restored order.<ref name="The Battle Of San Francisco"/> Marichal was ejected from the game and afterwards, National League president [[Warren Giles]] suspended him for eight games (two starts), fined him a then-NL record US$1,750<ref name=NYT1/><ref>{{cite news |title=MLBN Remembers ("Incident at Candlestick") |publisher=[[MLB Network|MLBN-tv]] |date=November 17, 2011}}</ref> ({{Inflation|US|1750|1965|r=-2|fmt=eq|cursign=$}}),{{Inflation-fn|US}} and also forbade him from traveling to [[Dodger Stadium]] for the final, crucial two-game series of the season.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> Roseboro filed a $110,000 damage suit against Marichal one week after the incident, but eventually settled out of court for $7,500.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/>
Years later, Roseboro stated that he was retaliating for Marichal having thrown at Wills.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> He explained that Koufax would not throw at batters for fear of hurting them due to the velocity of his pitches.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> He further stated that his throwing close to Marichal's ear was, "standard operating procedure", as a form of retribution.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> Marichal didn't face the Dodgers again until [[spring training]] in April 3, {{Baseball year|1966}}. In his first at bat against Marichal after the incident, Roseboro hit a three-run home run.<ref name="John Roseboro Hammers Homer In First Meeting With Juan Marichal">{{cite news |title=John Roseboro Hammers Homer In First Meeting With Juan Marichal |agency=Associated Press |work=The Day |page=25 |date=4 April 1966 |accessdate=30 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19660404&id=yuwgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wnIFAAAAIBAJ&pg=873,438492&hl=en}}</ref> San Francisco General Manager [[Chub Feeney]] approached Dodgers General Manager [[Buzzy Bavasi]] to attempt to arrange a handshake between Marichal and Roseboro, but Roseboro declined the offer.<ref name="John Roseboro Hammers Homer In First Meeting With Juan Marichal"/>
Dodger fans remained angry with Marichal for several years after the altercation, and reacted unfavorably when he was signed by the Dodgers in [[1975 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1975]]. By then, however, Roseboro had forgiven Marichal, and personally appealed to fans to do the same.<ref name = "boiling"/>
===Later career=== The Dodgers went on to win the [[1965 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1965]] National League Pennant by two games over the Giants. Even though the Giants won the two games against the Dodgers during which Marichal had been suspended, the outcome of the season may have been different without the Giants' pitcher's suspension, as he finished the season with a 22-13 [[Win–loss record (pitching)|win-loss]] record.<ref name="Marichal clubbing of Roseboro an ugly side of baseball"/> Roseboro once again guided the Dodgers' pitching staff to a league-leading 2.81 earned run average.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1965.shtml |title=1965 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> He caught for two twenty game winners in 1965 with Koufax winning 26 games, while [[Don Drysdale]] won 23 games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/LAD/1965.shtml |title=1965 Los Angeles Dodgers Batting, Pitching, & Fielding Statistics |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> In his book, ''[[The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract]]'', baseball historian [[Bill James]] said the decision to give [[Joe Torre]] a {{Baseball year|1965}} National League Gold Glove Award was absurd, stating that he was given the award because of his offensive statistics and that either Roseboro or [[Tom Haller]] was more deserving of the award.<ref name="The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract"/> In the [[1965 World Series]] against the [[1965 Minnesota Twins season|Minnesota Twins]], Roseboro contributed a two-run [[Single (baseball)|single]] to win Game 3 of the series as, the Dodgers went on to win the world championship in seven games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/LAN/LAN196510090.shtml |title=1965 World Series Game 3 box score |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1965_WS.shtml |title=1965 World Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref>
The Dodgers' pitching staff continued to lead the league in earned run average in [[1966 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1966]] as they battled with the [[1966 San Francisco Giants season|San Francisco Giants]] and the [[1966 Pittsburgh Pirates season|Pittsburgh Pirates]] in a tight pennant race.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1966.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::7 |title=1966 National League Team Pitching Statistics |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> The Dodgers eventually prevailed to win the National League Pennant for a second consecutive year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1966.shtml |title=1966 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> Roseboro led the league with a career-high 903 putouts and finished second to Joe Torre in fielding percentage to win his second Gold Glove Award.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1964-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1966 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1966 |title=1966 National League Gold Glove Award winners |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> The Dodgers would eventually lose the [[1966 World Series]], getting swept in four games by the [[1966 Baltimore Orioles season|Baltimore Orioles]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1966_WS.shtml |title=1966 World Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref>
The Dodgers would fall to 8th place in the [[1967 Los Angeles Dodgers season|1967]] season and Roseboro would be traded to the [[Minnesota Twins]] after the season with [[Bob Miller (baseball, born 1939)|Bob Miller]] and [[Ron Perranoski]] for [[Mudcat Grant]] and [[Zoilo Versalles]].<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/> While with the Twins, he would be named to his fourth and final All-Star team when he was named as a reserve for the [[American League]] team in the [[1969 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1969 All-Star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ALS/ALS196907230.shtml |title=1969 All-Star game |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=30 December 2015 }}</ref> After the season, Roseboro was released by the Twins.<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/> He signed as a [[free agent]] with the [[Washington Senators (1961–71)|Washington Senators]] on December 31, 1969 but appeared in only 46 games for the last place Senators.<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/> He played in his final major league game on August 11, [[1970 Washington Senators season|1970]] at the age of 37.<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/>
==Career statistics== In an fourteen-year major league career, Roseboro played in 1,585 [[Games played|games]], accumulating 1,206 [[Hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,847 [[at bats]] for a .249 career batting average along with 104 home runs, 548 runs batted in and an [[on-base percentage]] of .326.<ref name="John Roseboro at Baseball Reference"/> He had a .989 career fielding percentage as a catcher. Roseboro caught 112 [[shutouts in baseball|shutouts]] during his career, ranking him 19th all-time among major league catchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/tmonth1.htm |title=The Encyclopedia of Catchers - Trivia December 2010 - Career Shutouts Caught |publisher=The Encyclopedia of Baseball Catchers |accessdate=29 December 2015 }}</ref> He was the catcher for two of Sandy Koufax's four [[no-hitter]]s and caught more than 100 games in 11 of his 14 major league seasons.<ref name="John Roseboro Dies"/> Baseball historian Bill James ranked Roseboro 27th all-time among major league catchers.<ref name="The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract"/>
==Later life== After completing his playing career with Washington, Roseboro coached for the Senators (1971) and [[California Angels]] (1972–74). Later, he served as a [[Minor league baseball|minor league]] batting instructor (1977) and catching instructor (1987) for the Dodgers. Roseboro and his wife, Barbara Fouch Roseboro, also owned a [[Beverly Hills]] [[public relations]] firm.
Roseboro appeared as a [[Undercover operation#Plainclothes law enforcement|plainclothes]] officer in the 1966 ''[[Dragnet (series)#1966 television series|Dragnet]]'' TV movie. He also appeared as himself in the 1962 film ''[[Experiment in Terror]]'' along with [[Don Drysdale]] and [[Wally Moon]], and as himself in the 1963 ''[[Mister Ed]]'' episode "Leo Durocher Meets Mister Ed."<ref>{{cite web|title=John Roseboro|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0741771/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1|website=imdb|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref>
[[Chevrolet]] was one of the sponsors of the Dodgers' radio coverage in the mid-1960s. The song "See the USA in Your Chevrolet", made famous by [[Dinah Shore]] in the '50s, was sung in Chevrolet commercials by Roseboro and other Dodger players. Dodger announcer [[Jerry Doggett]] once joked that Roseboro was a singer "whose singing career was destined to go absolutely nowhere."
After several years of bitterness over their famous altercation, Roseboro and Marichal became friends in the 1980s.<ref name = "boiling">{{cite news |title=Baseball Boiling Over: 25 Years After Juan Marichal Clubbed John Roseboro |agency=Associated Press |work=Gettysburg Times |page=B1 |date=21 August 1990 |accessdate=30 December 2015 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19900821&id=oVwlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=j-YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1637,2098490&hl=en}}</ref> Roseboro personally appealed to the [[Baseball Writers' Association of America]] not to hold the incident against Marichal after he was passed over for election to the [[Baseball Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] in his first two years of eligibility. Marichal was elected in [[Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1983|1983]], and thanked Roseboro during his induction speech.<ref name="Put up your dukes"/><ref name="TBT">{{cite book |title=The Team-by-Team Encyclopedia of Major League Baseball |last=Purdy |first=Dennis |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2006 |publisher=[[Workman Publishing Company|Workman]] |location=New York City |isbn=0-7611-3943-5 |pages= }}</ref> "There were no hard feelings on my part," Roseboro said, "and I thought if that was made public, people would believe that this was really over with. So I saw him at a Dodger old-timers' game, and we posed for pictures together, and I actually visited him in the Dominican. The next year, he was in the Hall of Fame. Hey, over the years, you learn to forget things."<ref name="Put up your dukes"/>
Roseboro died of heart disease on August 16, 2002 in [[Los Angeles]] at age 69.<ref name="John Roseboro Dies"/> Marichal served as an honorary pallbearer at his funeral. "Johnny's forgiving me was one of the best things that happened in my life," he said, at the service. "I wish I could have had John Roseboro as my catcher."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/dodgers/la-sp-roseboro-marichal-plaschke-20150823-column.html|first=Bill|last=Plaschke|title=Fifty years after Giants' Juan Marichal hit Dodgers' John Roseboro with a bat, all is forgiven|date=22 August 2015}}</ref>

A '''liquid state machine''' ('''LSM''') is a particular kind of [[spiking neural network]]. An LSM consists of a large collection of units (called ''nodes'', or ''neurons''). Each node receives time varying input from external sources (the '''inputs''') as well as from other nodes. Nodes are [[random network|randomly connected]] to each other. The [[recurrent neural network|recurrent]] nature of the connections turns the time varying input into a [[spatio-temporal pattern]] of activations in the network nodes. The spatio-temporal patterns of activation are read out by [[Linear discriminant analysis|linear discriminant]] units.
The soup of recurrently connected nodes will end up computing a large variety of [[nonlinear function]]s on the input. Given a [[Typewriting monkeys|large enough variety]] of such nonlinear functions, it is theoretically possible to obtain linear combinations (using the read out units) to perform whatever mathematical operation is needed to perform a certain task, such as [[speech recognition]] or [[computer vision]].
The word [[liquid state|liquid]] in the name comes from the analogy drawn to dropping a stone into a still body of water or other liquid. The falling stone will generate [[Capillary wave|ripples]] in the liquid. The input (motion of the falling stone) has been converted into a spatio-temporal pattern of liquid displacement (ripples).
LSMs have been put forward as a way to explain the operation of [[brain]]s. LSMs are argued to be an improvement over the theory of artificial neural networks because:
#Circuits are not hard coded to perform a specific task. #Continuous time inputs are handled "naturally". #Computations on various time scales can be done using the same network. #The same network can perform multiple computations.
Criticisms of LSMs as used in [[computational neuroscience]] are that #LSMs don't actually explain how the brain functions. At best they can replicate some parts of brain functionality. #There is no guaranteed way to dissect a working network and figure out how or what computations are being performed. #Very little control over the process.
== Universal function approximation == If a reservoir has '''fading memory''' and '''input separability''', with help of a readout, it can be proven the liquid state machine is a universal function approximator using [[Stone-Weierstrass theorem]].<ref>{{citation |author1=Maass, Wolfgang |author2=Markram, Henry | year = 2004 | title = On the Computational Power of Recurrent Circuits of Spiking Neurons | journal = Journal of Computer and System Sciences | volume = 69 | issue = 4 | pages = 593–616 | doi = 10.1016/j.jcss.2004.04.001 }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Echo state network]]: similar concept in [[recurrent neural network]]. * [[Reservoir computing]]: the conceptual framework. * [[Self-organizing map]]
== Libraries == * LiquidC#: Implementation of topologically robust liquid state machine <ref>{{Citation |author1=Hananel, Hazan |author2=Larry, M., Manevit |title=Topological constraints and robustness in liquid state machines |journal=Expert Systems with Applications |volume=39 |issue=2 |pages=1597–1606 |date=2012 |doi=10.1016/j.eswa.2011.06.052 |url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0957417411009523 |postscript=. |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724025959/http://hananel.hazan.org.il/files/Publication/2012/Temporal%20Pattern%20Recognition%20via%20Temporal%20Networks%20of%20%20Temporal%20Neurons.pdf |archivedate=February 22, 2012 }}</ref> with a neuronal network detector [https://bitbucket.org/Hananel/liquid-state-machine]
== References == {{reflist}}
*{{Citation |author1=Maass, Wolfgang |author2=Natschläger, Thomas |author3=Markram, Henry |title=Real-time computing without stable states: a new framework for neural computation based on perturbations |journal=Neural Comput |volume=14 |issue=11 |pages=2531–60 |date=November 2002 |pmid=12433288 |doi=10.1162/089976602760407955 |url=http://ramsesii.upf.es/seminar/Maass_et_al_2002.pdf |postscript=. |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222154641/http://ramsesii.upf.es/seminar/Maass_et_al_2002.pdf |archivedate=February 22, 2012 }} *{{citation |author1=Wolfgang Maass |author2=Thomas Natschläger |author3=Henry Markram | title = Computational Models for Generic Cortical Microcircuits | journal = In Computational Neuroscience: a Comprehensive Approach, Ch 18 | volume = 18 | pages = 575–605 | date = 2004 }}

{{Infobox person | name = Long Beach Jane Doe | image = File:Long Beach Jane Doe.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = Digital image created from study of morgue photographs to depict an estimation of the victim in life | caption = Most recent reconstruction of the victim | birth_name = | birth_date = 1946 - 1954 (approximate) | birth_place = | disappeared_status = {{Unidentified for|1974|05|28}} | death_date = May 27, 1974 (aged 20-28) | death_place = Long Beach, California | death_cause = [[Homicide]] by [[strangling|strangulation]] | body_discovered = | other_names = Jane Doe 40, "Anna" | resting_place = | known_for = Unidentified victim of homicide | height = Approximately {{height|ft=5|in=5|abbr=mos}} | weight = Approximately {{convert|118|lb|kg}} | website = }}
'''Long Beach Jane Doe''' (known locally as '''Jane Doe 40''') is an unidentified murder victim whose body was found in May 1974. Her suspected murderer was arrested but she has never been identified, despite extensive investigation.
==Discovery of the body==
The [[Strangling|strangled]] body of a young woman was found on May 28, 1974, on the [[jetty]] of [[Alamitos Beach, Long Beach, California|Alamitos Beach]] in [[Long Beach, California]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Jane Doe -- 40|url=http://www.presstelegram.com/technology/20120602/jane-doe-40|accessdate=29 November 2014|work=Press Telegram|date=1 June 2012}}</ref>
She was estimated to be between 20 and 28 years old and had been [[rape]]d.<ref>{{cite web|title=Police Make Arrest In 1974 Homicide Case, Seek Assistance Identifying Victim|url=http://www.everythinglongbeach.com/police-make-arrest-in-1974-homicide-case-seek/|website=Everything Long Beach|date=7 June 2013}}</ref> Basic physical examination showed she was about 5 feet 5 inches tall and weighed about 118 pounds. The victim was white with possible [[Hispanic]] ancestry, as she had brown or black hair and brown eyes.<ref>{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4460|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/4460|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=29 November 2014|date=10 September 2008}}</ref> She also had a unique [[scar]] on the back of her left hand, which was shaped like the letter '''T'''. She also had an inch-long scar on the back of her left [[thigh]].
She was wearing a [[white gold]], 14-karat [[engagement ring]] with a small [[diamond]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Police Arrest Man For 1974 Murder — Now Just Have To Figure Out Who Victim Was|url=http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2013/06/05/police-arrest-man-for-1974-murder-now-just-have-to-figure-out-who-victim-was/|accessdate=29 November 2014|work=Los Angeles Local|agency=CBS Los Angeles|publisher=CBS|date=5 June 2013}}</ref> She was clothed in a pinkish-orange suit with a [[wikt:faux|faux]] black fur coat and calf-high [[suede]] boots.
The only items the Jane Doe carried were a house key and padlock key. The padlock key was attached to a broken chain.<ref>{{cite web|title=Case File 700UFCA|date=2 June 2012|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/700ufca.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref>
==Investigation==
[[File:700UFCA Recon 08-12-2014.jpg|thumb|150px|An additional reconstruction]]
No missing persons have been found who match the victim's description. Investigators have the girl's [[DNA profiling|DNA]] and fingerprints.<ref>{{cite web|title=LBPD Made Arrest in 39-year-old Case – Need Public's Help to Identify Victim|url=http://local.nixle.com/alert/5013078/|website=nixle.com|accessdate=29 November 2014|date=5 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Van Dyke|first1=Jonathan|title=Cold Case Solved, But Victim Still Unidentified|url=http://www.gazettes.com/news/crime/cold-case-solved-but-victim-still-unidentified/article_7800cd02-cefa-11e2-9a29-001a4bcf887a.html|accessdate=29 November 2014|publisher=Media News Group|date=6 June 2013}}</ref> A [[forensic facial reconstruction]] was created by the [[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]] to assist with identification.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murder, Rape Suspect of 1974 Jane Doe to be Arraigned|url=http://www.randomlengthsnews.com/murder-rape-suspect-of-1974-jane-doe-to-be-arraigned/|accessdate=29 November 2014|work=Random Lengths News|date=11 June 2013}}</ref>
===Arrest of Gary Stamp===
Police received a confession from a [[Texas]] man who claimed he had assisted with [[Dump job|dumping]] the victim's body. He led authorities to another suspect.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ruiz|first1=Jason|title=Arrest Made in 1974 Cold Case; Victim's Identity Still Unknown|url=http://lbpost.com/news/2000002425-a|accessdate=29 November 2014|work=Long Beach Post|date=7 June 2013}}</ref>
On May 20, 2013, a man named Gary Stamp (some sources state "Stump"), aged 61, was arrested. He confessed to the girl's murder but was not certain of her name, which may have been Anna.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cold Case: Gary Stamp arrested Gary Stamp for the murder of "Jane Doe #40" – Do you recognize her?|url=http://mylifeofcrime.wordpress.com/2013/06/06/cold-case-gary-stamp-arrested-gary-stamp-for-the-murder-of-jane-doe-40-do-you-recognize-her/|website=mylifeofcrime.wordpress.com|publisher=[[WordPress]]|accessdate=29 November 2014|date=6 June 2013}}</ref> Stamp was arraigned on June 12, 2013, in Superior Court.<ref>{{cite web|title=39-year-old cold case murder solved…halfway|url=http://www.crimevoice.com/39-year-old-cold-case-murder-solved-halfway/|website=Crime Voice|accessdate=29 November 2014|date=7 June 2013}}</ref>
The victim may have been seen at a [[Bar (establishment)|bar]] earlier. Stamp told police that he had met her at a bar.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Segura|first1=Joe|title=Long Beach police arrest man for 1974 murder|url=http://www.presstelegram.com/general-news/20130605/long-beach-police-arrest-man-for-1974-murder|accessdate=29 November 2014|work=Long Beach Press Telegram |date=4 June 2013}}</ref> Stamp would die of cancer while in police custody.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cold case team focuses on cracking cases|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2014/02/23/cold-case-team-focuses-on-cracking-cases/|website=The OCR|accessdate=9 April 2018|date=23 February 2014}}</ref>
