BRSCC Motorsport/[[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] Series Champion |before=[[David Walker (racing driver)|Dave Walker]] |after= [[Tony Brise]]|years= 1972}} {{s-end}} {{British F3 champions}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Williamson, Roger}} [[Category:English racing drivers]] [[Category:English Formula One drivers]] [[Category:March Formula One drivers]] [[Category:European Formula Two Championship drivers]] [[Category:British Formula Three Championship drivers]] [[Category:Racing drivers killed while racing]] [[Category:People from Ashby-de-la-Zouch]] [[Category:1973 deaths]] [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Filmed deaths in sports]] [[Category:Sport deaths in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]]

{{short description|Steel canaller lost with all hands on Lake Superior in 1914}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Benj. Noble sailing.jpg |Ship caption=The ''Benjamin Noble'' prior to her sinking }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag= {{flag|United States|merchant}} |Ship name=''Benjamin Noble'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder= Detroit Shipbuilding Company |Ship operator= Capitol Transportation Company |Ship identification= U.S Registry #206240 |ship yard number= 178 |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= April 28, 1909 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= 1909 |Ship out of service= 1914 |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport={{flag|United States}}, [[Detroit, Michigan]] |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship fate= Foundered April 29, 1914 off Knife River, Lake Superior |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type= [[canaller]] |Ship displacement= {{convert|1,481|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} |Ship length= {{convert|239|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|40|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height= {{convert|18|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= |Ship hold depth= |Ship propulsion=[[Triple expansion steam engine]] |Ship sail plan= |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship complement= |Ship Crew=16 [http://www3.gendisasters.com/minnesota/16111/two-harbors-mn-lake-superior-steamer-benjamin-noble-wrecked-apr-1914 GenDisasters website] |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox NRHP |embed=yes |name=''BENJAMIN NOBLE'' (Shipwreck) |image= |caption= |built=1909 |architect=Detroit Shipbuilding Company |architecture=Canaller |location=[[Lake Superior]] near [[Knife River, Minnesota|Knife River]] |coordinates ={{coord|46|56.00|N|91|40.00|W|display=inline,title}} |locmapin=Minnesota#USA |refnum=07000984{{NRISref|version=2010a}} |nearest_city=[[Duluth, Minnesota]] |added=2007 }} |} The '''SS ''Benjamin Noble''''' was a [[lake freighter]] that operated on the [[Great Lakes]]. Built in 1909 by the [[Dry Dock Complex (Detroit, Michigan)|Detroit Shipbuilding Company]], she was {{convert|239|ft|m}} in length and had a beam of {{convert|40|ft|m}}. She was built as a "[[canaller]]," a vessel designed for use in what were then the dimensions of the [[Welland Canal]], but was converted by her owners for services in the open Great Lakes. Heavily laden and top-heavy with a cargo of railroad rails, she sank in [[Lake Superior]] near [[Knife River, Minnesota]], in April 1914 with the loss of all hands{{cite book |first= Dwight |last= [[Dwight Boyer|Boyer]] |title= Ghost Ships of the Great Lakes |year= 1968 |publisher= [[Dodd, Mead and Company]] |location= New York |pages= 28–39}} in a storm. Of the estimated 16 crew members, only about the names of 10 are known.[http://www3.gendisasters.com/ship-wrecks/20767/update-on-quotbenjamin-noble-quot-lost-1914-partial-crew-list GenDisasters Website] On April 29, 1914 it was reported several crewmembers' remains were found on a sand reef near Minnesota Reef.[https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89074404/1914-04-29/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1914&index=2&rows=20&words=Benjamin+Noble+steamer&searchType=basic&sequence=0&sort=relevance&state=&date2=1914&proxtext=Steamer+Benjamin+Noble&y=17&x=4&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=3 Grand Forks daily herald and the evening times., April 29, 1914, Image 1] After more than 90 years as a [[ghost ship]], the hulk of the ''Benjamin Noble'' was rediscovered in the autumn of 2004. The wreck was placed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2007 as NRHP site #07000984.{{cite web |url=http://focus.nps.gov/AssetDetail/NRIS/07000984 |title=''Benjamin Noble'' (shipwreck) |publisher=[[National Park Service]] |accessdate=March 16, 2016 }} ==Design== The ''Benjamin Noble'' was unique among [[Lake freighter]]s because her stern cabins were elevated on a [[poop deck]]. Her bow cabins were also elevated on a [[forecastle]] deck. This also meant that she sat quite low in the water meaning that her [[spar deck]] often got wet. Maritime historian [[Dwight Boyer]] attributes the 1914 loss of the vessel to a combination of deliberate cargo overloading and the ship's unusual design. On her last voyage the low-riding vessel had very little [[Freeboard (nautical)|freeboard]] and was vulnerable to swamping. ==Discovery== In the Autumn of 2004 a shipwreck research team consisting of Jerry Eliason, Kraig Smith, Ken Merryman and Randy Beebe were searching for the [[SS Robert Wallace|''Robert Wallace'']] when their side scan sonar picked up the outlines of a shipwreck. Randy Beebe describes the event:
It was the last pass of the day, which was going to be the last day of the search season. We were just going to pull up the side-scan sonar and head in, and we noticed a target on the screen. So right away we headed over there and investigated it more with the side-scan sonar, and sure enough we had a shipwreck.{{cite web |url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2005/07/20_hemphills_superiorwreck/ |title=Mystery Ship Found |work=Minnesota Public Radio |accessdate=6 April 2018}}
The team was expecting to see the ''Wallace'', but the ship they found was made of steel. They were able to lower a camera into the cargo hold of the mystery ship. They saw railroad cars full of railroad tracks, this confirmed that the wreck was that of the long lost ''Benjamin Noble''. ==Victims== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Name !! Rank !! Notes |- | John Eisenhardt|| Captain|| from [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]][https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=jvrRlaHg2sAC&dat=19140429&printsec=frontpage&hl=en The Milwaukee Journal April 29, 1914 .pp.1-2 Obituary and picture of Captain Eisenhardt] |- | George R. Longley|| Mate|| from 1947 Whitney Avenue [[Niagara Falls, New York]] |- | John J. Cloonan|| Steward|| from [[Oswego, New York]] |- | Thomas Proud|| Steward|| from [[Oswego, New York]] |- | Anthony Bolcoroski|| Second Engineer || member of MEBA 37 |- | Alvin Conger|| Chief Engineer || from [[Port Clinton, Ohio]], member of MEBA 37, believed to have been engaged[https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88078751/1914-05-01/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=04%2F28%2F1914&index=1&rows=20&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&words=Coge%27r+Coger&proxdistance=5&date2=05%2F31%2F1914&ortext=&proxtext=Coger&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1 The Democratic Banner May 1, 1914 p.1 Mt Vernon Ohio] |- |Joel/Jed Conger|| Oiler || from [[Port Clinton, Ohio]], engaged to be married, brother of Alvin Conger |- | Frank Cougher|| Oiler|| from [[Port Clinton, Ohio]], |- |- | William Goulett|| Fireman|| from [[Toledo, Ohio]],Watertown NY Daily Times April 1914 |- | Alvin Guntch|| Fireman|| from [[Toledo, Ohio]], |- |6 other unidentified men|| unknown|| unknown |} ==See also== *[[List of shipwrecks in the Great Lakes]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Lake County, Minnesota]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{National Register of Historic Places in Minnesota}} {{NRHP in Lake County, Minnesota}} {{January-July 1914 shipwrecks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Benjamin Noble, SS}} [[Category:1909 ships]] [[Category:Great Lakes freighters]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1914]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Lake County, Minnesota]] [[Category:Ships lost with all hands]] [[Category:Shipwrecks of Lake Superior]] [[Category:Shipwrecks on the National Register of Historic Places in Minnesota]]

revision.text:
'''Superfetation''' (also spelled '''superfoetation''' and '''superfœtation''' – see [[fetus]]) is the simultaneous occurrence of more than one stage of developing offspring in the same animal.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roellig|first1=K|last2=Menzies|first2=BR|last3=Hildebrandt|first3=TB|last4=Goeritz|first4=F|title=The concept of superfetation: a critical review on a 'myth' in mammalian reproduction.|journal=Biological Reviews of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|date=February 2011|volume=86|issue=1|pages=77–95|doi=10.1111/j.1469-185X.2010.00135.x|pmid=20394608}}</ref> It is not believed that it occurs naturally in humans.<ref name=Mc2016/> There have been 10 reported cases of possible superfetation in humans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1926414,00.html|title=How Can a Pregnant Woman Get Pregnant Again?|author=Fletcher, Dan|publisher=Time Magazine|date=September 28, 2009|accessdate=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
In [[mammals]], it manifests as the formation of an embryo from a different [[estrous cycle]] while another embryo or fetus is already present in the [[uterus]]. When two separate instances of [[fertilisation]] occur during the same [[menstrual cycle]], it is known as [[superfecundation]].
Superfetation is claimed to be common in some species of animals. In [[mammals]], it can occur only where there are two uteri, or where the estrous cycle continues through [[pregnancy]].{{citation-needed|date=June 2018}}
==Other animals== Animals that have been claimed to be subject to superfetation include [[rodent]]s ([[mouse|mice]] and [[rat]]s), rabbits, [[horse]], [[sheep]], [[marsupials]] ([[kangaroo]]s and [[sugar glider]]s), felines, and [[primate]]s ([[humans]]). Superfetation has also been clearly demonstrated and is normal for some species of [[poeciliid]] [[fish]]es.<ref>[http://www.fishbase.org/glossary/Glossary.php?q=superfetation FishBase's glossary]</ref>
==Humans== While proposed cases of superfetation have been reported in humans, the existence of this phenomenon in humans is deemed unlikely.<ref name=Mc2016>{{cite journal|last1=McNamara|first1=HC|last2=Kane|first2=SC|last3=Craig|first3=JM|last4=Short|first4=RV|last5=Umstad|first5=MP|title=A review of the mechanisms and evidence for typical and atypical twinning.|journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=February 2016|volume=214|issue=2|pages=172–191|doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2015.10.930|pmid=26548710}}</ref> Better explanations include differential growth between twins due to various reasons such as [[twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome]].<ref name=Mc2016/> Artificially induced superfetation has been demonstrated, although only up to a short period after insemination.<ref name=Mc2016/>
In 2017, it was reported that an American woman who had agreed to act as a surrogate for a Chinese couple birthed two babies initially believed to be twins. Before the adoptive parents could return home to China, however, it was discovered that one of the babies was in fact the biological son of the surrogate. Doctors confirmed that the birth-mother had become pregnant with her and her partner's child roughly three weeks after becoming pregnant with the Chinese couple's child.<ref>http://www.insideedition.com/surrogate-mom-gets-pregnant-while-carrying-another-couples-baby-37644</ref>
There have been multiple cases reported to local US doctors with a week or less difference in age of twins and women who report two surges of ovulation occurring within a few days of each other. Though rare, this condition is believe to effect as many as .3% of women but often one twin is lost so the true numbers are not known.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Research has found 10% of women ovulate twice per month.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn3927-women-can-ovulate-more-than-once-a-month/|title=Women can ovulate more than once a month|last=Vince|first=Gaia|work=New Scientist|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://etd.lsu.edu/docs/available/etd-0730102-222405/unrestricted/Carter_dis.pdf Superfetation in Beef Cattle] Doctoral Thesis; Joel Andrew Carter, Louisiana State University, Defended 2002-03-18 * [http://www.fishbase.org/glossary/Glossary.php?q=superfetation Superfetation in fish]
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}

revision.text:
[[Image:1led0513adalen.jpg|thumb|300px|The peaceful part of the demonstration in Ådalen]] The '''Ådalen shootings''' ({{lang-sv|skotten i Ådalen}}) was a series of events in and around the sawmill district of [[Ådalen]], [[Kramfors Municipality]], [[Ångermanland]], [[Sweden]], in May 1931. During a protest on 14 May, five people were killed by bullets fired by [[Swedish military|troops]] called in as reinforcements by the police.
==Background== As a response to a drawn-out industrial conflict over pay reductions at the [[Wood pulp|pulp]] factory at Långrör, workers at other plants went on a [[sympathy strike]].<ref name="dn.se">{{cite news |url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/75-ar-sedan-skotten-i-adalen/ |newspaper=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |title=75 år sedan skotten i Ådalen |trans-title=75 years ago since the shooting in Ådalen |first=Tove |last=Nandorf |date=2006-05-13 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> The owner of the [[Graninge]] company, [[Gerhard Versteegh]], hired around 60 [[Strikebreaker|strike-breakers]], who arrived in the village of [[Lunde, Sweden|Lunde]] in Ådalen on 12 May. The workers held a protest rally in [[Kramfors]] and marched to the Sandviken plant north of the town, where they approached and attacked some of the strike-breakers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arbetetsmarknad.se/material/material-om-strejkbrytarna-i-adalen-1931/ |publisher=Arbetetsmarknad.se |title=Om strejkbrytarna i Ådalen 1931 |trans-title=About the strikebreakers in Ådalen 1931 |first=Roger |last=Johansson |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> Since the police had not been able to stop the attack, the [[County Administrative Boards of Sweden|County Administrative Board]] asked for the deployment of members of the military from [[Sollefteå]] to protect the strike-breakers. When the troops arrived in the late evening of 13 May, they were met by protesters, allegedly throwing stones.<ref name="dn.se"/>
==Confrontation== On 14 May the [[trade union|union]]s held another rally, during which the attending workers decided to stop all work in the timber and pulp industries in Ådalen—a [[general strike]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/ipadoriginal/article13025428.ab |newspaper=[[Aftonbladet]] |title=Massakern i Ådalen har tonats ner |trans-title=The massacre in Ådalen has been toned down |first=Svante |last=Lidén |date=2011-05-14 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> After the meeting, several thousand participants marched to the strike-breakers' quarters in Lunde, where the troops had been ordered to defend the strike-breakers. When they arrived in the village, a patrol of mounted troops tried unsuccessfully to stop them.<ref name="dn.se"/> In the confusion that followed, at least one man fell off his horse and another drew his pistol and fired warning shots while the patrol withdrew. The military commander, Capt. [[Nils Mesterton]], said later that he believed the demonstrators carried weapons since he heard shots as well as seeing some of the mounted patrol bleeding.<ref name="sverigesradio">{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/54030?programid=2519|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]] |title=Skotten i Ådalen −31 |trans-title=Ådalen shootings −31 |first=Sara |last=Lundin |date=30 October 2011 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> At a distance of less than 100 metres he, in accordance with orders from the present policeman in charge, ordered his troops to fire, which they did, aiming as planned at the ground halfway between the line and the demonstrators. However, ricochets hit the gathered demonstrators, who scattered, and the captain ordered the machine gun fired. Five people were shot to death: Oskar Berggren, Erik Bergström, Evert Nygren, Sture Larsson and Eira Söderberg, a 20-year-old bystander. Five people were injured. An inquiry later concluded that there was no evidence that the workers were in fact armed.<ref name="sverigesradio"/>
On that same day the County Administrative Board had decided to prohibit the strike-breakers from working. Their decision did not reach the demonstrators until after the shooting. It is widely believed that the confrontation could have been avoided if the news had reached the marchers earlier. The [[Confederation of Swedish Enterprise|Swedish Employers' Association]] later asked the [[Swedish Parliamentary Ombudsmen]] to review the decision.<ref name="dn.se"/>
==Aftermath== The events spawned a raging national debate, deeply divided along political lines. The political left called the shootings "murder", while the right claimed that the military had been forced to open fire to defend themselves and the "willing workers" from the rage of the demonstrators.<ref name="dn.se"/><ref name="socialisterna.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.socialisterna.org/sv/2/1/6772/ |publisher=[[Socialist Justice Party]] |title=Dödsskotten i Ådalen den 14 maj 1931 ekar ännu |trans-title=The shootings in Ådalen on May 14, 1931 still echoes |first=Per |last=Olsson |date=10 May 2011 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> The publishers of several left-wing newspapers were convicted for violations against the limitations in the [[Constitution of Sweden#Freedom of the press and freedom of expression|Freedom of the Press Act]].<ref name="sverigesradio"/> Major demonstrations took place in [[Stockholm]].<ref name="socialisterna.org"/>
The County Governor was tried in court but acquitted. Capt. Mesterton and Capt. Beckman were initially convicted in a [[court martial]], but were acquitted on appeal and that verdict was confirmed by the [[Swedish Supreme Court|supreme court]]. Sgt. Rask and Sgt. Tapper, who were manning the machine gun, were also put on trial since repositioning had been performed with a loaded weapon, which was against army regulations.<ref name="sverigesradio1">{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3993&artikel=4503640 |publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]] |title=Skotten i Ådalen förändrade Sverige för alltid |trans-title=Ådalen shootings changed Sweden forever |first=Jonas |last=Hultström |date=14 May 2011 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> Rask was acquitted while Tapper was found guilty and sentenced to three days' confined arrest with loss of pay. On the other hand, several demonstrators had to face severe sentences: Axel Nordström, considered to be the leader, was sentenced to two and half years' imprisonment with [[Penal labour|hard labor]]. No [[damages]] were awarded to the wounded demonstrators or to the families of the five dead.<ref name="socialisterna.org"/>
The government, under the liberal [[Prime Minister of Sweden|Prime Minister]] [[Carl Gustaf Ekman]], replaced the County Governor and launched an investigation into the event.<ref name="sverigesradio1"/> The investigation, with representatives from both employers and trade unions, later concluded that the military was highly unfit to uphold public order in similar situations.<ref name="Prop"/> The use of the military against civilians was more strictly regulated, but the legislation was on the books until it was repealed by the 1969 [[Riksdag]]. However, there was broad political agreement not to use military force against civilians.<ref>[http://www.adalen1931.se/ Ådalen 1931] Retrieved 9 May 2015</ref> The Ådalen shootings were still a concern in the discussions after the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 events]] in the US, when military support to the police was considered. Therefore, the subsequent legislation that allowed the military to take part in anti-terrorism actions contained several safeguards. The military must be under command of the police, as they were in Ådalen in 1931, and legislation specifically says that the military cannot be used against demonstrations.<ref name="Prop">{{cite web|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/Webbnav/index.aspx?nid=37&dok_id=GT03111|title=Regeringens proposition 2005/06:111 – Försvarsmaktens stöd till polisen vid terrorismbekämpning |trans-title=Government Bill 2005/06: 111 – The Armed Forces support to police in counter-terrorism |publisher=Riksdagsförvaltningen |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://lagen.nu/2006:343 |publisher=Lagen.nu |title=Lag (2006:343) om Försvarsmaktens stöd till polisen vid terrorismbekämpning |trans-title=Act (2006: 343) of the Armed Forces support to police in counter-terrorism |accessdate=13 November 2010 |language=Swedish}}</ref> There was still concern that these safeguards would not be enough.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stockholmsfria.nu/artikel/7163 |newspaper=[[Stockholms Fria Tidning]] |title=Lagen kan användas mot allt som inte passar sig |trans-title=The law can be used against anything that does not fit in |last=Andersen |first=Ivar |date=13 May 2006 |accessdate=13 November 2010 |language=Swedish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stockholmsfria.nu/artikel/7182 |newspaper=[[Stockholms Fria Tidning]] |title=Militären föreslås få bruka tvång och våld mot civila |trans-title=The military proposes to use force and violence against civilians |last=Svanebro |first=Karin |date=10 May 2006 |accessdate=13 November 2010 |language=Swedish}}</ref><ref name="svd.se">{{cite news |url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/skotten-som-formade-sverige_6163885.svd |newspaper=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |title=Skotten som formade Sverige |trans-title=The shots that shaped Sweden |first=Karin |last=Thurfjell |date=14 May 2011 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref>
At the time of the 1931 events, it was not possible to call in police reinforcements from outside the county.<ref name="svd.se"/> Thus, army assistance was the only recourse available to a county governor when the county's police force would be insufficient to deal with large-scale events. The shootings highlighted the inadequacy of this state of affairs. One effect of the Ådalen shootings was the formation of a national police force in 1933.<ref name="sverigesradio1"/>
The leadership of the Social Democratic banned members to attend the funerals of the killed protesters as they were regarded as collaborators with the revolutionary communist party.
==Coverage in film== In 1969 well-known Swedish [[Film director|filmmaker]] [[Bo Widerberg]] told the story of the events in his film ''[[Ådalen 31]]'' (released as ''Adalen Riots'' in the US). Partly thanks to the film and partly through the persistent use of the events in political debate, the Ådalen shootings are still well known in Sweden, and are sometimes referred to in connection with violent clashes between demonstrators and police such as the 2001 [[protests during the EU summit in Gothenburg 2001|EU summit protests in Gothenburg]].<ref name="sverigesradio1"/>
The incident is also mentioned several times in the 1979 Swedish comedy film ''[[Repmånad]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfi.se/sv/svensk-filmdatabas/Item/?itemid=5033&type=MOVIE&iv=Comments |publisher=[[Swedish Film Database]] |title=Repmånad eller Hur man gör pojkar av män (1979) |access-date=9 May 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref>
